original_text: In his letters to the Corinthians, the apostle Paul outlines the only true gospel, calling it “the simplicity that is in Christ”.
prompt: 0: A detailed image of the apostle Paul outlining the only true gospel during the writing of his letters to the Corinthians, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: Notwithstanding this instruction, Paul feared that some might seek to counter the simple truths he taught, and thus he counseled the believers not to accept another Jesus and another gospel: Paul was wary that after sharing the simple truth about God and His Son, others would come along to share a false gospel, preaching another Jesus and another Spirit.
prompt: 10: A detailed image of Paul counseling the believers not to accept another Jesus and another gospel during his teaching, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: What’s more, Paul predicted that the church “might well bear with [or accept] him [the false teacher]”! Sadly, Paul’s fear has become a reality. The vast majority of Christian churches today proclaim a trinity god.
prompt: 20: A detailed image of the church bearing with the false teacher and proclaiming a trinity god during Paul's prediction, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: Another gospel has come in. I implore you not to be deceived into thinking that this is a minor matter.
prompt: 30: A detailed image of the arrival of another gospel and the implore not to be deceived, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: Either the message contained within this book is the false gospel, or the doctrine of the Trinity is. Most certainly, the two beliefs couldn’t be further apart from each other.
prompt: 40: A detailed image of the message within the book and the contrast between the false gospel and the doctrine of the Trinity, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: As you’ll soon discover, one teaching is based purely upon passages of plain Scripture, while the other is founded upon suppositions and speculative theories. Friends, study carefully. There is no middle ground.
prompt: 50: A detailed image of the discovery of two teachings based on Scripture and speculative theories, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: For the purpose of unraveling the Protestant perspective of the trinity, I will be using quotations from leaders of the Seventh-day Adventist Church, and at times comparing these statements with those from the Roman Catholic Church.
prompt: 60: A detailed image of unraveling the Protestant perspective of the trinity through the use of quotations and comparisons with the Roman Catholic Church, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: To begin, we find that the Adventist Church defines the trinity as follows: There isn’t a single verse in the Bible which teaches that God is a unity of three co-eternal persons.
prompt: 70: A detailed image of the definition of the trinity by the Adventist Church, highlighting the absence of a verse in the Bible teaching a unity of three co-eternal persons, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: On the contrary, the Bible declares: Interestingly, Jesus was once asked by a scribe: “Which is the first [greatest] commandment of all?” (Mark 12:28).
prompt: 80: A detailed image of the Bible's declaration and Jesus being asked about the first commandment, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: As was often His custom, the Lord answered by quoting from the Old Testament Scriptures.
prompt: 90: A detailed image of the Lord quoting from the Old Testament Scriptures as His custom, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: Yet notice which passage Jesus references in answer to this question: In answer to the question, “Which is the first commandment of all?” Jesus recalls Deuteronomy 6:4, underlining the importance of believing in one God.
prompt: 100: A detailed image of Jesus referencing Deuteronomy 6:4 to underline the importance of believing in one God in response to the question about the first commandment, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: In his letter to the Corinthians, the apostle Paul clearly outlines who that one God is: Paul plainly declares that there is “one God, the Father”.
prompt: 110: A detailed image of the apostle Paul outlining the identity of the one God as the Father in his letter to the Corinthians, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: This is reiterated in his letter to the Ephesians, where he states: By comparing John 17:3 with Mark 12:29, it becomes abundantly clear that when Jesus quoted the Shema of Israel (“Hear, O Israel; The Lord our God is one Lord”), He was referring to His Father; “the only true God”.
prompt: 120: A detailed image of the Apostle Paul reiterating the identity of the one true God as the Father in his letter to the Ephesians and the comparison between John 17:3 and Mark 12:29, taken with a DSLR camera, using a standard lens with cinematic lighting --v 5.2 --ar 16:9

original_text: The Father is the source of all life, including the life of His Son ( John 5:26). This is why Jesus is called the “only begotten Son of God” ( John 3:18).

original_text: He is equal with God in nature. And the Bible tells us that the Father created all things through His Son (Ephesians 3:9, Hebrews 1:2).

original_text: However, in holding to this teaching, trinitarians are forced to reject plain passages of Scripture spoken by Christ Himself, and even those spoken by the Father in heaven.

original_text: When one is making these types of statements—which are being distributed worldwide—solid scriptural support must be shown, and that which does not contradict other Scripture!

original_text: We often forget that these are the very words of Christ, and that this is the gospel which has to transcend to every nation, kindred, tongue, and people. The gospel that even a child can understand!

original_text: Surely, you don’t need a theologian to tell you what “only begotten” means. It’s a simple, self-explanatory truth.

original_text: Consider the following exceptionally plain passages: The Bible teaches that to know God is to love Him, and one comes to love God by believing in who He is and what He’s done for them.

original_text: Friends, God sent His only begotten Son into the world to save you. Not someone playing the role of a Son. Not a metaphor. His only begotten Son. These are all plain statements.

original_text: They are not metaphors, and neither are they symbolic. In fact, God sought to make it so clear that He spoke twice from heaven concerning this very point.
